## Discriminate green macrophytes using remote sensing {auto-animate="true" style="font-size: 60px;"}
### Conclusion

::: {.absolute top="0" left="95%"}
::: sectionhead
[1]{style="opacity:0.25"} 2 [3 4 5 6]{style="opacity:0.25"}
:::
:::

::: {.absolute bottom="0%" right="-2%"}
[7]{style="color: black;"}
:::

::: {.absolute .fragment .fade-in fragment-index="1" top="30%" left="0%"}
![](Images/BedePaperCover.png){height="500"}
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in fragment-index="1" .incremental .absolute top="12%" left="53%" style="font-size: 35px; line-height: 1.3; margin: 10px; padding: 40px; text-align: justify-all;"}
- [Key points:]{style="font-size: 60px"}
    - The study assessed the ability to [distinguish between five different vegetative intertidal habitats]{style="color: red"} by analyzing their spectral reflectance signatures.
    - Around 366 spectra were compiled along the European Atlantic coast, from Southern Spain to Northern France.
    - The spectral library was analyzed at [various multi- and hyperspectral resolutions]{style="color: red"}, comparing satellite and drone sensors.
    - The analysis highlighted the effectiveness of a random forest spectral classification model in [differentiating between differently pigmented habitats and even between similarly pigmented classes]{style="color: red"}.
    - High accuracy in distinguishing vegetation was found for hyperspectral sensors and multispectral sensors with more than [eight bands in the visible and near-infrared]{style="color: red"}.
    - The study [provides insights for the next generation of satellite missions]{style="color: red"} regarding optimal spectral resolution and important wavelengths for effective monitoring of intertidal ecosystems.
:::
